choices.text: Jaquemier’s sign
Hegar’s sign
Osiander’s sign
Robert’s sign

questions.text: A 23-year woman presents to the OPD. She is recently married and has missed her period and is overdue by 2 weeks. She wants to know if she is pregnant or not. If she is pregnant which will NOT be seen on clinical examination?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Robert’s sign

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s Discuss all Options:

 

  • Option D. Robert sign is the presence of a gas shadow in the aorta and other large vessels following intra-uterine fetal demise.
  • Option A, B, C. Jaquemier, Hegar and Osiander signs are all seen in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Named Pelvic signs

 

 

 

Finding it Difficult to remember? These may help!

 

  • “Jack & Chad had a blue van. Ossy’s pulse increased.”
  • “A soft cervix is good”

 

Ref:  Page 61; DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics; 9th edition

choices.text: Palmer sign
Piscacek’s sign
Placental sign
Hegar’s sign

questions.text: A 23-year primigravida presents at 6 weeks with spotting. She is very anxious. On ultrasound, there is a single live intrauterine fetus corresponding to 6 weeks and cardiac activity is seen. She is reassured that this spotting could be normal and due to fusion of the decidua. What is this sign known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Placental sign

 

Explanation:

 

Placental sign is mild bleeding/ spotting which may be seen before complete fusion of the decidua vera with the decidua capsularis and is also called implantation bleed; It may be cyclical and may last till 12 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Palmer sign, Piscacek’s sign and Hegar sign are all clinical signs of pregnancy in the 1st trimester

 

Educational Objective:

 

The named signs in pregnancy are:

 

 

Ref: Page 61; DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics; 9th edition

choices.text: It can detect βhCG in the urine and appears before βhCG can be detected in the blood.
Most pregnancy test detect the α subunit of beta hCG
Maximum level of hCG is reached at about 50 days of a missed period
Tests based on ELISA are positive on the 1st day of a missed period.

questions.text: A 25-year woman has missed her period. She does a urine pregnancy test at home to see if she is pregnant. Which is correct regarding the urine pregnancy test?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Tests based on ELISA are positive on the 1st day of a missed period.

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s Discuss all options:

 

  • Option A. It can detect βhCG in the urine and appears before βhCG can be detected in the blood. This is incorrect. First beta hCG appears in the blood and then in the urine
  • Option B. Most pregnancy tests detect the α subunit of beta hCG: This is also incorrect. Most tests detect the beta subunit of hCG
  • Option C. Maximum level of hCG is reached at about 50 days of a missed period. This is also incorrect. Maximum levels of beta hCG are at 10 weeks (70-80 days)
  • Option D. Tests based on ELISA are positive on the 1st day of a missed period. This is a correct statement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pregnancy tests depend on detection of the antigen (hCG); usually the beta unit, present in the maternal urine or serum with antibody either polyclonal or monoclonal available commercially
  • Maximum levels of beta hCG are at 10 weeks (70-80 days)
  • Serum detection of hCG is earlier than detection of hCG in the urine
  • ELISA based tests are positive as early as on the 1st day of a missed period (urine) and 4-5 days before a missed period (serum)

 

 

Ref: Page 62, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics; 9th edition

choices.text: A follow up ultrasound after 2 weeks is advised
Beta hCG to be done with serial monitoring
Laparoscopy and salpingotomy
Inj Methotrexate 50mg/m2

questions.text: A 28-year G2 presents at 5 weeks pregnancy with mild abdominal pain. On examination, there is no pallor, and her vital signs are stable. An ultrasound reveals the following. Which is correct regarding this?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A follow up ultrasound after 2 weeks is advised

 

Explanation:

 

  • This image shows an intra-uterine gestational sac which is seen at 5 weeks of pregnancy
  • As a gestational sac is seen, the next best step would be to follow up with a repeat ultrasound after 10 – 14 days to look for the fetal pole and cardiac activity.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Beta hCG to be done with serial monitoring: This is indicated when the ultrasound does not show anything, i.e. a pregnancy of unknown location.
  • Option C. Laparoscopy and salpingotomy: This is indicated in an unruptured ectopic pregnancy. In this case the gestational sac is seen in the uterus.
  • Option D. Inj Methotrexate 50mg/m2 : This is indicated in a patient with unruptured ectopic pregnancy but in this case, the gestational sac is seen in the uterus

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Features of an intra-uterine gestational sac:
    • Eccentric
    • Regular and round
    • Double decidual sac sign seen
    • Intra-decidual sac sign seen
    • Yolk sac seen (at 5.5 weeks)
    • Associated peripheral vascularity seen
  • Order of appearance of structures on a Trans-vaginal Scan in an intra-uterine pregnancy (These appear 1 week later on a Trans-abdominal scan)
    • 5 weeks: Gestational sac
    • 5.5 weeks: Yolk sac (1st anatomic structure to be seen in the gestational sac)
    • 6 weeks: Fetal pole with cardiac activity

 

Ref:  Page 158, William’s Obstetrics; 25th edition

choices.text: 6 – 8 weeks
10 – 12 weeks
14 – 16 weeks
18 – 20 weeks

questions.text: A woman presents to the antenatal OPD. She is not sure of her dates. On abdominal examination, external ballottement is elicited. When is the earliest, this sign can be seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 18-20 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

External Ballotment is as shown below. It appears at 18-20 weeks

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

This is External Ballotment. External Ballottement can be elicited after 18-20 weeks by a push to the fetal parts with one hand abdominally and the other hand receiving the impulse

 

 

  • This is internal Ballottement. It can be elicited at 16 weeks by a push to the fetal parts with the two fingers through the anterior fornix.

 

 

 

Ref: Page 62, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics; 9th edition

choices.text: External Ballotment
Fetal Heart auscultated
Hegar’s Sign
The uterine fundus is palpated at the upper border of the umbilicus

questions.text: A 27-year primigravida visits the antenatal OPD at 24 weeks. An intern examines the patient. Which is NOT an expected finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hegar’s sign

 

  • Hegar’s sign is observed at 6 – 10 weeks. On bimanual examination, the vaginal and abdominal fingers seem to approximate as the upper part of the body of the uterus is enlarged due to the fetus; the lower part of the body is empty and soft and the cervix is comparatively firmer

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: External ballotment appears at 18-20 weeks
  • Fetal heart can be auscultated by 20 weeks
  • The uterine fundus is palpated at the lower border of the umbilicus at 20 weeks

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the 2nd trimester, the following are seen:

 

  • On Inspection:
    • Striae gravidarum and linea nigra are seen
  • On Palpation:
    • Uterus palpable at 12 – 14 weeks, lower border of umbilicus at 20 weeks and upper border at 24 weeks
    • External ballotment at 18-20 weeks
    • Internal ballotment after 16 weeks
    • Fetal Heart rate can be auscultated as early as 20 weeks

 

Ref: Page 64, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics; 9th edition

choices.text: A blighted ovum
A missed abortion
An ectopic pregnancy
An intrauterine pregnancy

questions.text: An intra-decidual sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. An intrauterine pregnancy

 

Explanation:

 

2 important signs on USG in early intrauterine pregnancy:

 

  1. Intra-decidual sign – An anechoic center surrounded by a single echogenic rim
  2. Double decidual sign – 2 concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. A blighted ovum: In a blighted ovum, on ultrasound, no fetal pole is seen even at a mean sac diameter of 25mm
  • Option B. A missed abortion: This is defined as either the absence of cardiac activity even when the fetal pole is 7mm or the disappearance of an earlier present cardiac activity
  • Option C. An ectopic pregnancy: An unruptured ectopic will have several ultrasound signs including 
  • A pseudo sac
  • A gestational sac in the adnexal region
  • Bagel sign
  • Blob sign
  • Ring of fire sign

 

Educational Objective:

 

2 important signs on USG in early intrauterine pregnancy:

 

  1. Intra-decidual sign – An anechoic center surrounded by a single echogenic rim
  2. Double decidual sign – 2 concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac

 

Double decidual sac sign:

 

  • is a useful feature on early pregnancy ultrasound to confirm an early intrauterine pregnancy (IUP) 
  • Especially useful when the yolk sac or embryo is still not visualized
  • It consists of the decidua parietalis (decidua lining the uterine cavity) and decidua capsularis (decidua lining the gestational sac)
  • It is seen as two concentric rings surrounding an anechoic gestational sac.

 

Where the two adhere is the decidua basalis, and is the site of future placental formation



 

Intra-decidual sac sign

 

  • Earliest sign of an intrauterine pregnancy on ultrasound
  • Gestational sac seen eccentric to central endometrial cavity line
  • Rapidly progresses to double decidual sac sign if the pregnancy is normal

choices.text: Majority of women complain of increased vomiting in the morning
Excessive vomiting is seen more in women with single than multiple fetuses
80% are relieved by 14 weeks
It more commonly occurs in women with a h/o migraine

questions.text: A 23-year primigravida presents at 8 weeks. She complains of nausea and occasional vomiting. Which is true regarding nausea and vomiting in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. It more commonly occurs in women with a h/o migraine

 

Let’s Discuss all the Options:

 

  • Option A. Majority of women complain of increased vomiting in the morning: This is an incorrect statement. Erroneously called morning sickness as it can occur at any time and is not specific to the morning

 

  • Option B. Excessive vomiting is seen more in women with single than multiple fetuses: This is incorrect. Multiple pregnancy is associated with hyperemesis.

 

  • Option C. 80% are relieved by 14 weeks: This is incorrect; 50% are relieved by 14 weeks and 90% by 22 weeks

 

  • Option D. It more commonly occurs in women with a h/o migraine. This is a correct statement

 

Educational Objective:

 

About Hyperemesis Gravidarum

 

  • Nausea and vomiting in pregnancy is a common symptom;
  • It is seen in about 70 % of all pregnant women.
  • Erroneously called morning sickness as it can occur at any time and is not specific to the morning
  • Starts in the 1sttrimester
  • 50% are relieved by 14 weeks and 90% by 22 weeks.
  • More common in
    • Multiple pregnancy
    • Molar pregnancy (Increased βhCG)
    • h/o nausea and vomiting in an earlier pregnancy
    • h/o nausea and vomiting with OCPs
    • Mother or sister with morning sickness during pregnancy
    • h/o migraine

 

Ref: Page 158, William’s Obstetrics; 25th edition; Page no 117, Gabbe Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Maternal obesity
Multiple pregnancy
Anterior placenta
Fetal demise

questions.text: A 21-year primigravida presents at 21 weeks. She is anxious as she has still not perceived “Quickening”. All are possible reasons except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Multiple pregnancy

 

Explanation:

 

  • Multiple pregnancy will result in earlier quickening and not in delayed quickening
  • Delayed quickening is seen in
    • Anterior placenta
    • Maternal obesity
    • Polyhydramnios or oligohydramnios
    • Fetal demise

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • “Quickening” is “feeling of life”
  • It is usually felt at about the 18th week in primis and 2 weeks earlier in multis.
  • Its appearance is a useful guide to see how accurate the dating is especially in women who are unsure of their LMP and do not have an early trimester ultrasound.
  • Delayed quickening is seen in
    • Anterior placenta
    • Maternal obesity
    • Polyhydramnios or oligohydramnios
    • Fetal demise

 

Ref: Page no 63, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

choices.text: Early pregnancy
Ectopic pregnancy
Missed abortion
Pregnancy of unknown location

questions.text: A 28-year primigravida presents with amenorrhoea. Her UPT is positive. She is not sure of her LMP. An ultrasound is done which shows the following. Which is NOT a possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Missed abortion

 

Explanation:

 

  • The ultrasound shows uterus with a normal endometrial lining. There is no evidence of an intra-uterine gestational sac seen.
  • The following possibilities thus arise: (Option A, B and D)

 

  1. A very early pregnancy. An intrauterine gestational sac is visible on ultrasound only when the serum beta hCG crosses a certain value. This is called the discriminatory zone and is 6000IU/ml for transabdominal scans and 1500 IU/ml for transvaginal scans. If the beta hCG is below 1500, a gestational sac will not be seen
  2. An ectopic pregnancy: The image seen is only of the uterus. An ectopic pregnancy which is very early also may not be apparent on ultrasound
  3. A pregnancy of unknown location: This is when there is no evidence of pregnancy on the ultrasound despite the urine pregnancy test being positive. Serial beta hCG tests are done in such scenarios

 

  • Option C. In a missed abortion, on ultrasound, there will be an intrauterine gestational sac seen on ultrasound. A missed abortion is diagnosed when an earlier cardiac activity is not seen or when the CRL is 7 mm but no cardiac activity is seen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a missed abortion, there will be an intrauterine gestational sac seen on ultrasound. A missed abortion is diagnosed when an earlier cardiac activity is not seen or when the CRL is 7 mm but no cardiac activity is seen.

 

Ref: Page 158, William’s Obstetrics; 25th edition

choices.text: a4 b3 c2 d1
a1 b3 c2 d4
a2 b4 c3 d1
a2 b3 c4 d1

questions.text: Match the following change with the period of gestation seen in?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. a2 b3 c4 d1

 

Explanation:

 

  • Internal Ballotment (can be elicited at 16 weeks by a push to the fetal parts with the two fingers through the anterior fornix):  seen between 16 – 28 weeks
  • FHR is 1st auscultated by stethoscope at 18-20 weeks
  • Hegar’s sign (On bimanual exam, the abdominal and vaginal fingers approximate below the body of the uterus) is seen between 8 – 12 weeks
  • Lightening occurs (Feeling of dropping down of the baby in the pelvis) at 38 weeks

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Internal Ballotment (can be elicited at 16 weeks by a push to the fetal parts with the two fingers through the anterior fornix):  seen between 16 – 28 weeks
  • FHR is 1st auscultated by stethoscope at 18-20 weeks
  • Hegar’s sign (On bimanual exam, the abdominal and vaginal fingers approximate below the body of the uterus) is seen between 8 – 12 weeks
  • Lightening occurs (Feeling of dropping down of the baby in the pelvis) at 38 weeks

 

Ref:  Page 61; DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics; 9th edition

choices.text: Clinical examination
Serum beta hCG
Urine beta hCG
Ultrasound

questions.text: A 23-year woman presents with 6 weeks amenorrhoea. She is not unsure if she is pregnant or not. Which is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Clinical examination

 

Explanation:

 

  • In the question, the next best step is asked
  • A clinical examination always precedes any investigation

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Serum HCG: This is indicated only in situations with a positive urine pregnancy test, but nothing seen on the ultrasound (pregnancy of unknown location)

 

  • Option C. Urine HCG: This would be the most practical step especially and is usually done in a patient with suspected pregnancy. However, in the ideal setting, and for answering in an exam, a clinical exam always precedes tests.

 

  • Option D. Once pregnancy is suspected on clinical exam or the urine pregnancy test is positive, a TVS is done.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with suspected pregnancy, examination is always the next immediate step

 

Ref:  Page 60; DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics; 9th edition

choices.text: FHR will be auscultated
Linea nigra will be seen
Internal ballotment will be present
Uterus will be palpable just above the pubic symphysis

questions.text: A 28-year G2 presents to the antenatal OPD. She is 14 weeks gestation and this is her 1st visit. She has 1 child who is 3 years old delivered vaginally. Which will be seen on examination in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Uterus will be palpable just above the pubic symphysis

 

Explanation:

 

  • At 14 weeks, the uterus will be palpable (just above the pubic symphysis)

 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. FHR will be auscultated for the first time 18-20 weeks
  • Option B. Linea nigra appears at 18-20 weeks
  • Option C. Internal ballotment is seen between 16-28 weeks

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • Linea nigra appears at 18-20 weeks
  • FHR is auscultated first between 18-20 weeks
  • Internal ballotment is seen between 16-28 weeks
  • External ballotment is seen at 20 weeks

choices.text: Accurate LMP
CRL on ultrasound
Date of coitus
Date of quickening

questions.text: The most accurate determination of gestational age in a pregnancy is by:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CRL on ultrasound

 

Explanation

 

  • Crown-Rump Length (CRL) is the most accurate measurement of gestational age with a variation of ± 5 days.

 

Other options: LMP, date of coitus or date of quickening are not as accurate as CRL for determination of gestational age.

 

Educational Objective: Crown-Rump Length (CRL) is the most accurate measurement of gestational age with a variation of ± 5 days.

 

Ref: Page No 186, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Which of these graphs accurately represents βHCG variation in normal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. B

 

Explanation:

 

  • βhCG is produced by syncytiotrophoblasts
  • βhCG increases in the 1st trimester and reaches a peak at 10 weeks.
  • Doubling time in early pregnancy is 1.4-2 days
  • It then declines slowly to reach a plateau at 14-16 weeks
  • This is how βhCG values appears on a graphical representation

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • βhCG increases in the 1st trimester and reaches a peak at 10 weeks.
  • Doubling time in early pregnancy is 1.4-2 days
  • It then declines slowly to reach a plateau at 14-16 weeks
  • This is how βhCG values appears on a graphical representation

 

 

Ref: Page No:158, William’s Obstetrics 25th

choices.text: Serum hCG measurement
Urine hCG pregnancy test
Transvaginal ultrasound
Serum progesterone measurement

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic with concerns about a possible pregnancy. She has missed her last two menstrual periods. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test after a clinical examination at this stage in the OPD?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Urine hCG pregnancy test

 

Explanation: The most appropriate initial diagnostic test to confirm pregnancy is a urine hCG pregnancy test also called a UPT. Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is produced by the placenta and can be detected in urine as early as 7-10 days after conception. This is a sensitive and non-invasive method for pregnancy confirmation.

 

Ref:  Page 60; DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics; 9th edition

choices.text: Serum hCG measurement
Urine hCG pregnancy test
Transvaginal ultrasound
Pelvic exam

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with irregular menstrual cycles presents with nausea and breast tenderness. She suspects pregnancy and wants to know the earliest test that can provide accurate results. Which diagnostic test is the most sensitive for early pregnancy detection?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Serum hCG measurement

 

Explanation: Serum hCG measurement is the most sensitive diagnostic test for early pregnancy detection. It can detect hCG in the blood within 7-10 days after conception, making it a valuable tool in the early stages of pregnancy when urine tests might not yet yield positive results.

 

Other options

 

  • Option B. Urine hCG: This is positive 2-3 days after a missed period
  • Option C. TVS: This shows a gestational sac at 5 weeks
  • Option D. Pelvic exam: Earliest signs on pelvic exam appear at 6-8 weeks

 

Educational Objective: The earliest test of pregnancy is a serum bhCG. This is positive 7-10 days post conception

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 25th edition pg 158

choices.text: Transvaginal ultrasound
Pelvic exam
Urine hCG pregnancy test
Serum progesterone measurement

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman in her first trimester presents for a prenatal visit. Her last menstrual period (LMP) was 8 weeks ago. On physical examination, the uterus is not palpable abdominally. What is the next best step in confirming the gestational age of the pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Transvaginal ultrasound

 

Explanation: A transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) provides precise dating and can measure the crown-rump length (CRL) to estimate the gestational age accurately.

 

Other Options

 

  • Option B. Pelvic exam: This is not accurate to determine gestational age
  • Option C. Urine hCG: will confirm the presence of hCG but will not tell us the date
  • Option D. Serum progesterone rises in pregnancy but this does not corelate with the dating of pregnancy

 

Educational Objective: The most reliable test for dating pregnancy is a TVS by measuring the crown rump length (CRL)

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 25th edition pg 159

choices.text: Serum hCG measurement
Urine hCG pregnancy test
Transvaginal ultrasound
Serum progesterone measurement

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with a history of ectopic pregnancy presents with abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She suspects she might be pregnant. Which diagnostic test is essential in this situation to rule out an ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Transvaginal ultrasound

 

Explanation:

 

  • In a woman with a history of ectopic pregnancy and symptoms of abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding, it is crucial to rule out another ectopic pregnancy. Transvaginal ultrasound is the preferred diagnostic test as it can visualize the uterus and adnexa and determine the location of the pregnancy, which is essential in cases of suspected ectopic pregnancy.
  • If the TVS is inconclusive, then the next best step would be to do a serum bhCG doubling (0h and 48h)

 

Other Options

 

  • Option A: Serum hCG will not be the initial test do diagnose an ectopic. Only if the ultrasound is inconclusive, do we check the serum bhCG at 0h and 48h
  • Option B: Urine bhCG just confirm pregnancy. It does not tell us the site of pregnancy
  • Option D: Serum progesterone levels increase in pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

A patient with amenorrhoea (early pregnancy) and bleeding or pain, the first test done is always a Transvaginal scan (TVS)

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 25th edition pg 159
